2022_2023.summary: Slight improvements in gender balance and racial diversity. First-time appointees increased by 5%.

2023_2024.summary: Gender balance achieved. Continued increase in diversity and first-time appointee representation.

2024_2025.summary: Slight regression in female representation. Racial diversity continues to improve. First-time appointees decreased slightly.

Gender.trend: Minor regression but still above parity

overall_2022_2025_trends.summary: Over the 4-year period from 2022 to 2025, Brooklyn Community Boards saw significant improvements in gender balance (+3.7% female representation) and racial diversity (Black representation +4.9%, Hispanic +2.9%, White -8.2%). First-time appointees increased by 6 percentage points overall, indicating improved board renewal.

major_increases.significance: Achieved and maintained above-parity female representation
Largest racial/ethnic group increase, better reflecting Brooklyn demographics
Steady growth reflecting Brooklyn's growing Hispanic population
Indicates board renewal and fresh perspectives

major_decreases.significance: Boards becoming more representative of Brooklyn's diversity

gender_balance.trend_summary: Gender balance improved from 48.3% female in 2022 to 52.0% female in 2025, achieving and maintaining above-parity representation. The 2024 peak of 53.0% female representation saw a slight decrease in 2025, but overall trend shows sustained progress toward gender equity.

age_distribution.trend_summary: Boards are gradually getting younger, with 18-44 age group increasing from 27.6% to 34.3% (+6.7 percentage points), while 65+ decreased from 21.2% to 18.5%.

boards_with_biggest_changes.details: Increased female representation from 42% (2022) to 59% (2025), largest improvement among all boards
Black representation increased from 55% to 68%, reflecting neighborhood demographics
18-44 age group increased from 25% to 42%, attracting younger residents

community_board_changes.notes: Community Board 4, 9, and 1 showed the most significant demographic shifts, with improvements in representation across multiple categories. Boards in gentrifying neighborhoods (CB1, CB2) saw largest increases in younger appointees, while historically Black neighborhoods (CB9, CB16, CB17) maintained strong Black representation while improving gender balance.

first_time_vs_returning.trend_summary: First-time appointees increased from 32% (2022) to 38% (2025), with a peak of 41% in 2024. This indicates healthy board renewal and engagement of new community members.

data_quality_notes: Data was extracted from Brooklyn Borough President's annual demographic reports (2022-2025). Categories and definitions remained consistent across all years. Some boards had incomplete data in 2022 report. Non-binary gender data was not tracked until potentially 2025 (shows 0% across all years in available data). Educational attainment and length of residence data was inconsistently reported and excluded from year-over-year analysis.
